These cells are approximately the same size as large lymphocytes and have a large granular intracytoplasmic inclusion called a Kurloff body. The Kurloff body is composed of sulfated proteoglycan that is rich in mucopolysaccharide and appears homogeneous, finely granular, or slightly vacuolated (Jain, 2004). The Kurloff body stains with toluidine blue and is PAS-positive. The nucleus of Foa-Kurloff cells is large and round and is usually eccentrically placed.
body_text.section: Foa-Kurloff Cells ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Guinea Pig

body_text.text: The exact origin and function of Foa-Kurloff cells are not known, but they lack lysosomes and phagocytic activity and may serve as natural killer (NK) cells in circulation (Pouliot et al., 1996). Foa-Kurloff cells are rarely seen in young animals or in males, and their presence in females is correlated with estrogen levels (Percy and Barthold, 2007). These cells are common in pregnant guinea pigs and may be induced by estrogen to shift from the lungs and red pulp of spleen to the thymus and placenta (Moore, 2000). It is thought that Foa-Kurloff cells may help form a barrier between mother and fetus during pregnancy by protecting fetal antigens in the placenta (Pilny, 2008).
body_text.section: Foa-Kurloff Cells ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Guinea Pig

body_text.text: The reference range for platelet number in guinea pigs is 250–850×106 per µl (Table 3.10), although the values are variable in the literature (Feldman et al., 1982). Guinea pig platelets have an irregular oval shape of approximately 2–3 microns in length, a pale periphery, and a darkly staining center.
body_text.section: Platelets (Thrombocytes) ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Guinea Pig

body_text.text: Platelet numbers in guinea pigs are affected by factors such as age, strain, and disease. Platelet numbers were found to decrease between 100 and 200 days of age, followed by an increase, in male Weiser-Maples guinea pigs (Kitagaki et al., 2005). The hairless strain of Dunkin-Hartley guinea pigs were found to have higher platelet numbers compared to normal Dunkin-Hartley guinea pigs (Waner et al., 1996).
body_text.section: Platelets (Thrombocytes) ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Guinea Pig

body_text.text: Inflammation in the guinea pig is associated with an increase in platelets, which can exceed one million per microliter without an increase in total leukocyte numbers (Riggs, 2009).
body_text.section: Platelets (Thrombocytes) ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Guinea Pig

body_text.text: The reference range for myeloid to erythroid ratio in normal guinea pigs is 1.5:1 to 1.9:1 (Table 3.8).
body_text.section: Bone Marrow ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Guinea Pig

body_text.text: Blood collection in the hamster is described in Clinical Biochemistry section above.
body_text.section: Blood ::: Sample Collection ::: Hamster

body_text.text: Reference values for blood and plasma volumes in the hamster are provided in Table 3.8.
body_text.section: Blood Volume ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Hamster

body_text.text: The reference range for blood volume of the Syrian hamster is 6.8–12 ml or 65–80 ml per kg body weight (Table 3.8).
body_text.section: Total Blood Volume ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Hamster

body_text.text: Due to the hamster’s ability to conserve water, 72 hours of water deprivation in this species causes decreased whole blood volume and plasma volumes with little or no change in hematocrit (Kutscher, 1968). Hibernation in the hamster causes an increase in blood volume and other hematologic parameters (Hrapkiewicz and Medina, 2007). However, the site of blood collection reportedly has little effect on hematologic parameters in the hamster.
body_text.section: Total Blood Volume ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Hamster

body_text.text: The volume of a single blood sample in the hamster is 0.5–1.3 ml per 2 weeks (Table 3.8).
body_text.section: Total Blood Volume ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Hamster

body_text.text: The total exsanguination volume in the hamster is 3–5 ml (Table 3.8).
body_text.section: Total Blood Volume ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Hamster

body_text.text: Water deprivation for 72 hours was found to decrease plasma volume in the hamster (Kutscher, 1968).
body_text.section: Plasma Volume ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Hamster

body_text.text: Reference values for erythrocyte parameters in the hamster are provided in Table 3.9.
body_text.section: Erythrocytes ::: Peripheral Blood Cells ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Hamster

body_text.text: The reference range for total number of red blood cells in the hamster is 2.7–12.3×106 cells per µl (Table 3.9).
body_text.section: Red Blood Cell Count ::: Peripheral Blood Cells ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Hamster

body_text.text: Hibernation in the hamster causes an increase in red blood cell number (Heatley and Harris, 2009; Hrapkiewicz et al., 1998). Castration decreases circulating RBCs by 25–30% in male hamsters due to decreased testosterone levels (Heatley and Harris, 2009). There have been no red blood cell antigen differences identified in hamsters.
body_text.section: Red Blood Cell Count ::: Peripheral Blood Cells ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Hamster

body_text.text: The reference range for hematocrit value in the hamster is 30–59% (Table 3.9) and is affected by several factors (Burns and De Lannoy, 1966). For example, hematocrit increases with age in hamsters. The neonatal hamster is relatively anemic, with a hematocrit of 34–39%. At this age red cells are characterized by hypochromia and macrocytosis, with 10–30% normoblasts (Gad, 2007). Ten to 30% of circulating red blood cells are nucleated in neonatal hamsters, compared to less than 2% in adults (Jain, 1974).
body_text.section: Hematocrit (Hct) or Packed Cell Volume (PCV) ::: Peripheral Blood Cells ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Hamster

body_text.text: Hibernation in the hamster causes an increase in PCV and other hematologic parameters, accompanied by decreased red blood cell destruction (Hrapkiewicz and Medina, 2007).
body_text.section: Hematocrit (Hct) or Packed Cell Volume (PCV) ::: Peripheral Blood Cells ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Hamster

body_text.text: The reference range for hemoglobin level in the hamster is 10–19.2 g/dl (Table 3.9) and is affected by factors such as age and hibernation state. Hemoglobin increases to a maximum concentration in hamsters at 8–9 weeks of age (Gad, 2007), although some studies report little change in hemoglobin levels between 1 and 27 weeks old (Rennie et al., 1981).
body_text.section: Hemoglobin (hgb) ::: Peripheral Blood Cells ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Hamster

body_text.text: Hibernation causes increased Hgb concentration (Heatley and Harris, 2009), and hypothermia causes more complete oxygen saturation of hemoglobin than normothermia (Volkert and Musacchia, 1970).
body_text.section: Hemoglobin (hgb) ::: Peripheral Blood Cells ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Hamster

body_text.text: The reference range for erythrocyte lifespan in the hamser is 50–78 days (Table 3.9).
body_text.section: Erythrocyte Lifespan ::: Peripheral Blood Cells ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Hamster

body_text.text: Hibernation causes increased life span of erythrocytes in the hamster (Mitchell and Tully, 2009).
body_text.section: Erythrocyte Lifespan ::: Peripheral Blood Cells ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Hamster

body_text.text: The reference range for erythrocyte diameter in the hamster is 5–7 microns (Table 3.9).
body_text.section: Erythrocyte Size and Staining ::: Peripheral Blood Cells ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Hamster

body_text.text: Normal young hamsters (4–8 weeks old) have microcytic normochromic red blood cells with some variation in size and shape, as well as occasional spherocytes and target cells. Polychromasia and Howell-Jolly bodies are found normally in healthy hamsters (Pilny, 2008). Polychromasia is seen more often in hamsters than in humans (Gad, 2007). Hamster red blood cells are nucleated 2% of the time.
body_text.section: Erythrocyte Size and Staining ::: Peripheral Blood Cells ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Hamster

body_text.text: The reference range for MCV in the hamster is 64–78 µ3 (Table 3.9).
body_text.section: Mean Cell Volume (MCV) ::: Peripheral Blood Cells ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Hamster

body_text.text: Most hamster erythrocyte values are similar to those of the rat, although MCV is slightly higher in the hamster (Dent, 1977).
body_text.section: Mean Cell Volume (MCV) ::: Peripheral Blood Cells ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Hamster

body_text.text: The reference range for MCH in the hamster is 20–26 pg per cell (Table 3.9).
body_text.section: Mean Cell Hemoglobin (MCH) ::: Peripheral Blood Cells ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Hamster

body_text.text: The reference range for MCHC in the hamster is 28–37 g/dl (Table 3.9).
body_text.section: Mean Cell Hemoglobin Concentration (MCHC) ::: Peripheral Blood Cells ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Hamster

body_text.text: The end of hibernation in the hamster is associated with an increase in reticulocyte numbers (Hrapkiewicz and Medina, 2007).
body_text.section: Reticulocytes ::: Peripheral Blood Cells ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Hamster

body_text.text: The reference range for total leukocyte count in the hamster is 3–15×103 cells per µl (Table 3.10) and varies with several factors including age, sex, strain, diurnal rhythm, hibernation, and disease.
body_text.section: Total White Blood Cell (wbc) Count ::: Leukocytes ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Hamster

body_text.text: Neonatal Syrian hamsters have a total leukocyte count of approximately 2000 cells per microliter. White blood cells increase with age in European hamsters, from 3500 per microliter at 13 days to 8200 per microliter at 65 days and are higher in males than females (Emminger et al., 1975).
body_text.section: Total White Blood Cell (wbc) Count ::: Leukocytes ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Hamster

body_text.text: Total white blood cell count in Chinese hamsters is higher in the middle of the light cycle than in the middle of the dark cycle (Lappenbusch, 1972).
body_text.section: Total White Blood Cell (wbc) Count ::: Leukocytes ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Hamster

body_text.text: Hibernation causes a decrease in total white blood cell count in Syrian hamsters from 5000–10 000 per microliter to 2500 per microliter (Heatley and Harris, 2009; Mitruka and Rawnsley, 1977), although the NP:LC ratio remained at 1:1 (Hrapkiewicz and Medina, 2007).
body_text.section: Total White Blood Cell (wbc) Count ::: Leukocytes ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Hamster

body_text.text: In European hamsters, hibernation is also associated with a lower total white blood cell count and platelet count, with unchanged differential distribution (Reznik et al., 1975). White cell numbers fall to a low of 100 per microliter during hibernation in this strain (Heatley and Harris, 2009). After hibernation, a leukocytosis characterized by neutrophilia occurs, with 70–90% neutrophils and a total leukocyte count of 10 000–20 000 cells per microliter (Heatley and Harris, 2009; Pilny, 2008).
body_text.section: Total White Blood Cell (wbc) Count ::: Leukocytes ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Hamster

body_text.text: Hamsters experimentally infected with pirital virus, a novel arenavirus isolated from the cotton rat (Sigmodon astoni) in Venezuela, demonstrate leukocytosis, including neutrophilia, eosinophilia, and basophilia on days 5–6 post-infection (Sbrana et al., 2006).
body_text.section: Total White Blood Cell (wbc) Count ::: Leukocytes ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Hamster

body_text.text: The reference range for total lymphocyte count in the hamster is 50–96% (Table 3.10). Lymphocytes are the predominant circulating leukocyte in hamsters, comprising 60–80% of the differential leukocyte count (Heatley and Harris, 2009). Most hamster lymphocytes are small round cells with a dark-blue nucleus that occupies the majority of the cell, surrounded by a rim of lighter-blue cytoplasm. Hibernation in the hamster causes decreased WBC numbers, with a 1:1 NP:LC ratio (Hrapkiewicz and Medina, 2007).
body_text.section: Lymphocytes ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Hamster

body_text.text: The reference range for total neutrophil count in the hamster is 17–35% (Table 3.10). As in many other rodents, hamster neutrophils are also called heterophils because they resemble eosinophils, with a lobular nucleus and dense pink cytoplasmic granules. Hamster neutrophils have a diameter of approximately 10–12 microns. Hamster neutrophils have moderate alkaline phosphatase activity (Tamburlin and Glomski, 1988) but lack lysozyme activity (Thrall et al., 2004).
body_text.section: Neutrophils (Heterophils) ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Hamster

body_text.text: Hibernation in the hamster causes decreased WBC numbers, with a 1:1 NP:LC ratio (Hrapkiewicz and Medina, 2007). At the end of hibernation, neutrophilic leukocytosis occurs, with 70–90% neutrophils and total leukocyte count of 10 000–20 000 cells per microliter (Heatley and Harris, 2009).
body_text.section: Neutrophils (Heterophils) ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Hamster

body_text.text: The reference range for total eosinophil count in the hamster is 0–5% (Table 3.10). Hamster eosinophils are similar in appearance to those of other rodent species.
body_text.section: Eosinophils ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Hamster

body_text.text: The reference range for total basophil count in the hamster is 0–5% (Table 3.10). Hamster basophils are similar in appearance to those of other rodent species.
body_text.section: Basophils ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Hamster

body_text.text: The reference range for total monocyte count in the hamster is 0–5% (Table 3.10). Hamster monocytes are similar in appearance to those of other rodent species.
body_text.section: Monocytes ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Hamster

body_text.text: The reference range for total platelet count in the hamster is 200–590×106 per µl (Table 3.10) and varies with hibernation and disease. Hibernation causes decreased platelet counts in European hamsters (Reznik et al., 1975) and Syrian hamsters (Heatley and Harris, 2009).
body_text.section: Platelets (Thrombocytes) ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Hamster

body_text.text: Hamsters experimentally infected with pirital virus had increased platelet numbers on days 5 and 6 post-infection (Sbrana et al., 2006).
body_text.section: Platelets (Thrombocytes) ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Hamster

body_text.text: The reference range for bleeding time in the hamster is 1.5–2.4 minutes (Table 3.11).
body_text.section: Bleeding Time (BT) ::: Coagulation ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Hamster

body_text.text: The reference range for prothrombin time in the hamster is 10.3–10.7 seconds (Table 3.11).
body_text.section: Prothrombin Time (PT) ::: Coagulation ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Hamster

body_text.text: Female hamsters have shorter prothrombin times than males (Dodds et al., 1977).
body_text.section: Prothrombin Time (PT) ::: Coagulation ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Hamster

body_text.text: Hamsters experimentally infected with pirital virus had increased PT by 8 days post-infection (Sbrana et al., 2006).
body_text.section: Prothrombin Time (PT) ::: Coagulation ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Hamster

body_text.text: The reference range for fibrinogen concentration in the hamster is 188–316 g/dl (Table 3.11). Female hamsters have higher concentrations of fibrinogen and plasminogen than males (Dodds et al., 1977).
body_text.section: Fibrinogen Concentration ::: Coagulation ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Hamster

body_text.text: The adult hamster has a highly cellular bone marrow, with a myeloid to erythroid ratio of approximately 0.9:1 (Table 3.8) (Gad, 2007). The largest cells in the hamster bone marrow are megakaryocytes. There are also significant numbers of eosinophils, plasma cells, histiocytes, and a few mast cells (Gad, 2007). The neonatal hamster bone marrow is primarily erythroblastic. The spleen does not play a major role in erythropoiesis in the hamster and becomes erythropoietically active only when stimulated by T3 (Boussios et al., 1982).
body_text.section: Bone Marrow ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Hamster

body_text.text: Gerbil restraint techniques and blood collection are described in the Clinical Biochemistry section of this chapter.
body_text.section: Blood ::: Sample Collection ::: Gerbil ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: Reference values for blood volume in the gerbil are provided in Table 3.8.
body_text.section: Blood volume ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Sample Collection ::: Gerbil ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: The reference range for blood volume in the gerbil is 4.4–8 ml, or 67ml per kg body weight (Table 3.8).
body_text.section: Total Blood Volume ::: Sample Collection ::: Gerbil ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: A single blood sample volume in the gerbil is 0.4–1.3 ml per 2 weeks (Table 3.8).
body_text.section: Total Blood Volume ::: Sample Collection ::: Gerbil ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: The exsanguination volume of blood in the gerbil is 2–4 ml (Table 3.8).
body_text.section: Total Blood Volume ::: Sample Collection ::: Gerbil ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: Reference values for erythrocyte parameters in the gerbil are provided in Table 3.9.
body_text.section: Erythrocytes ::: Peripheral Blood Cells ::: Gerbil ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: The reference range for red blood cell count in the gerbil is 7–10×106 cells per µl (Table 3.9).
body_text.section: Red Blood Cell (RBC) Count ::: Peripheral Blood Cells ::: Gerbil ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: Neonatal gerbils have erythrocyte counts that are approximately half the adult values but increase to adult values by about 8 weeks of age (Pilny, 2008).
body_text.section: Red Blood Cell (RBC) Count ::: Peripheral Blood Cells ::: Gerbil ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: The reference range for hematocrit in the gerbil is 35–52% (Table 3.9).
body_text.section: Hematocrit (Hct) or Packed Cell Volume (PCV) ::: Peripheral Blood Cells ::: Gerbil ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: Male gerbils have higher hematocrit values than females (Heatley and Harris, 2009).
body_text.section: Hematocrit (Hct) or Packed Cell Volume (PCV) ::: Peripheral Blood Cells ::: Gerbil ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: The reference range for hemoglobin concentration for the gerbil is 10–17.9 g/dl (Table 3.9).
body_text.section: Hemoglobin (Hgb) ::: Peripheral Blood Cells ::: Gerbil ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: The erythrocyte lifespan in the gerbil averages 10 days (Table 3.9), which represents a much faster turnover rate than seen in other laboratory animals (Joslin, 2009).
body_text.section: Erythrocyte Lifespan ::: Peripheral Blood Cells ::: Gerbil ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: Gerbils up to 20 weeks old have a large number of circulating reticulocytes and erythrocytes with basophilic stippling and polychromasia. These cells are also abundant in older gerbils and are probably associated with the short erythrocyte lifespan (Heatley and Harris, 2009; Pilny, 2008).
body_text.section: Erythrocyte Lifespan ::: Peripheral Blood Cells ::: Gerbil ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: Neonatal gerbils have macrocytic erythrocytes, but this condition resolves by approximately 8 weeks of age (Pilny, 2008).
body_text.section: Erythrocyte Size and Staining ::: Peripheral Blood Cells ::: Gerbil ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: The reference range for MCV in the gerbil is 46.6–60 µ3 (Table 3.9) and is elevated in neonatal gerbils until approximately 8 weeks old (Pilny, 2008).
body_text.section: Mean Cell Volume (mcv) ::: Peripheral Blood Cells ::: Gerbil ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: Male gerbils have higher MCV values than females (Heatley and Harris, 2009).
body_text.section: Mean Cell Volume (mcv) ::: Peripheral Blood Cells ::: Gerbil ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: The reference range for MCH in the gerbil is 16.1–19.4 pg per cell (Table 3.9).
body_text.section: Mean Cell Hemoglobin (MCH) ::: Peripheral Blood Cells ::: Gerbil ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: The reference range for MCHC for the gerbil is 30.6–33.3 g/dl (Table 3.9).
body_text.section: Mean Cell Hemoglobin Concentration (MCHC) ::: Peripheral Blood Cells ::: Gerbil ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: MCHC values are higher in male gerbils than in female gerbils (Heatley and Harris, 2009).
body_text.section: Mean Cell Hemoglobin Concentration (MCHC) ::: Peripheral Blood Cells ::: Gerbil ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: Gerbils up to 20 weeks old have a large number of circulating reticulocytes and erythrocytes with basophilic stippling and polychromasia. These cells are also abundant in older gerbils and are probably associated with the short erythrocyte lifespan (Heatley and Harris, 2009; Pilny, 2008).
body_text.section: Reticulocytes ::: Peripheral Blood Cells ::: Gerbil ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: The reference range for white blood cell count in the gerbil is 4.3–21.6×103 cells per µl (Table 3.10).
body_text.section: Total White Blood Cell (WBC) Count ::: Leukocytes ::: Gerbil ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: Neonatal gerbils have panleukocytosis that resolves by approximately 8 weeks old (Pilny, 2008). Male gerbils have higher total leukocyte counts than females (Heatley and Harris, 2009).
body_text.section: Total White Blood Cell (WBC) Count ::: Leukocytes ::: Gerbil ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: The reference range for lymphocyte count in the gerbil is 32–97% (Table 3.10).
body_text.section: Lymphocytes ::: Leukocytes ::: Gerbil ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: The predominant leukocyte in gerbils is the lymphocyte, which is much more abundant than granulocytes in this species (Dillon and Glomski, 1975).
body_text.section: Lymphocytes ::: Leukocytes ::: Gerbil ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: Male gerbils have higher total leukocyte count due to a higher number of lymphocytes. The lymphocyte-to-heterophil ratio in the male is 6:1 compared to 3:1 in the female (Heatley and Harris, 2009).
body_text.section: Lymphocytes ::: Leukocytes ::: Gerbil ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: The reference range for neutrophil count in the gerbil is 2–41% (Table 3.10).
body_text.section: Neutrophils (Heterophils) ::: Leukocytes ::: Gerbil ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: Gerbil neutrophils have moderate alkaline phosphatase activity (Tamburlin and Glomski, 1988).
body_text.section: Neutrophils (Heterophils) ::: Leukocytes ::: Gerbil ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: The reference range for eosinophil count in the gerbil is 0–4% (Table 3.10).
body_text.section: Eosinophils ::: Leukocytes ::: Gerbil ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: The reference range for basophil count in the gerbil is 0–2% (Table 3.10).
body_text.section: Basophils ::: Leukocytes ::: Gerbil ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: The reference range for monocyte count in the gerbil is 0–9% (Table 3.10).
body_text.section: Monocytes ::: Leukocytes ::: Gerbil ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: The reference range for platelet number in the gerbil is 400–830×106 per µl (Table 3.10).
body_text.section: Platelets (Thrombocytes) ::: Gerbil ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: The reference range for myeloid to erythroid ratio in the gerbil is 0.75:1 to 2.35:1 (Table 3.8).
body_text.section: Bone Marrow ::: Gerbil ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: Blood collection in the chinchilla is described above in the section on Clinical Biochemistry.
body_text.section: Blood ::: Sample Collection ::: Chinchilla ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: The reference range for blood volume in the chinchilla is 20–32 ml (Table 3.8).
body_text.section: total Blood Volume ::: Blood Volume ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Chinchilla ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: Volume of a single blood sample in the chinchilla is 2–7 ml per 2 weeks (Table 3.8).
body_text.section: total Blood Volume ::: Blood Volume ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Chinchilla ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: Exsanguination volume in the chinchilla is 8–12 ml (Table 3.8).
body_text.section: total Blood Volume ::: Blood Volume ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Chinchilla ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: Reference values for erythrocyte parameters in the chinchilla are provided in Table 3.9.
body_text.section: Erythrocytes ::: Peripheral Blood Cells ::: Chinchilla ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: The reference range for red blood cell count in the chinchilla is 5–10×106 cells per µl (Table 3.9).
body_text.section: Red Blood Cell Count ::: Peripheral Blood Cells ::: Chinchilla ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: The reference range for hematocrit in the chinchilla is 30–55% (Table 3.9).
body_text.section: Hematocrit (Hct) or Packed Cell Volume (PCV) ::: Peripheral Blood Cells ::: Chinchilla ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: The packed cell volume, hemoglobin concentration, and MCHC values are higher in blood obtained from chinchillas anesthetized with ketamine and xylazine than in blood obtained by cardiac puncture post-mortem (de Oliveira Silva et al., 2005).
body_text.section: Hematocrit (Hct) or Packed Cell Volume (PCV) ::: Peripheral Blood Cells ::: Chinchilla ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: The reference range for hemoglobin concentration for the chinchilla is 9–15 g/dl (Table 3.9).
body_text.section: Hemoglobin (Hgb) ::: Peripheral Blood Cells ::: Chinchilla ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: The reference range for MCV in the chinchilla is 32.1–69.2 µ3 (Table 3.9).
body_text.section: Mean Cell Volume (MCV) ::: Erythrocyte Size and Staining ::: Peripheral Blood Cells ::: Chinchilla ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: The reference range for MCH in the chinchilla is 10.4–19.8 pg/cell (Table 3.9).
body_text.section: Mean Cell Hemoglobin (MCH) ::: Peripheral Blood Cells ::: Chinchilla ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: The reference range for MCHC in the chinchilla is 20–38.5 g/dl (Table 3.9).
body_text.section: Mean Cell Hemoglobin Concentration (MCHC) ::: Peripheral Blood Cells ::: Chinchilla ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: The reference range for leukocyte number in the chinchilla is 4–25×103 cells per µl (Table 3.10). Total leukocyte number is higher in blood obtained from male chinchillas anesthetized with ketamine and xylazine compared to blood obtained by cardiac puncture post-mortem (de Oliveira Silva et al., 2005).
body_text.section: Total White Blood Cell (WBC) Count ::: Leukocytes ::: Chinchilla ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: The reference range for lymphocyte number in the chinchilla is 19–98% (Table 3.10).
body_text.section: Lymphocytes ::: Leukocytes ::: Chinchilla ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: The lymphocyte is the most common circulating leukocyte in the chinchilla. The chinchilla responds to inflammation with an early increase in neutrophils and decrease in lymphocytes, resulting in little change in the total leukocyte count (Riggs and Mitchell, 2009).
body_text.section: Lymphocytes ::: Leukocytes ::: Chinchilla ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: The reference range for neutrophil number in the chinchilla is 9–78% (Table 3.10). The neutrophil is the second most common circulating leukocyte in the chinchilla (Riggs and Mitchell, 2009). The chinchilla neutrophil has a nucleus that may be hyposegmented, similar to the Pelger-Huet anomaly in the rabbit. Heterophils lack myeloperoxidase, the enzyme that liquefies purulent material, causing chinchilla pus to be thick and caseous (Riggs and Mitchell, 2009).
body_text.section: Neutrophils ::: Leukocytes ::: Chinchilla ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: The reference range for eosinophil number in the chinchilla is 0–9% (Table 3.10). These cells are uncommon in the circulation of normal chinchillas (Riggs and Mitchell, 2009).
body_text.section: Eosinophils ::: Leukocytes ::: Chinchilla ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: The reference range for basophil number in the chinchilla is 0–11% (Table 3.10). These cells are uncommon in the circulation of normal chinchillas (Riggs and Mitchell, 2009).
body_text.section: Basophils ::: Leukocytes ::: Chinchilla ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: Basophil and monocyte numbers were lower in blood obtained from male chinchillas anesthetized with ketamine and xylazine compared to blood obtained by cardiac puncture post-mortem (de Oliveira Silva et al., 2005).
body_text.section: Basophils ::: Leukocytes ::: Chinchilla ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: The reference range for monocyte number in the chinchilla is 0–6% (Table 3.10). These cells are uncommon in the circulation of normal chinchillas (Riggs and Mitchell, 2009).
body_text.section: Monocytes ::: Leukocytes ::: Chinchilla ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: The reference range for platelet number in the chinchilla is 300–600×106 per µl (Table 3.10). A dramatic increase in platelets, of more than 1000 per ml, may occur in response to inflammation in the chinchilla (Riggs and Mitchell, 2009).
body_text.section: Platelets (Thrombocytes) ::: Chinchilla ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: There is little specific information available on the hematologic characteristics of the degu.
body_text.section: Degu ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: The degu is a diurnal rodent and has been the subject of many studies of the effect of circadian rhythm on physiology, behavior, and disease states.
body_text.section: Degu ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: Hematologic and serum protein values for degus of both sexes and all ages studied are reported to be similar to those of other laboratory rodents (Murphy et al., 1978).
body_text.section: Degu ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: Blood collection in the deer mouse is described above in the section on Clinical Biochemistry.
body_text.section: Blood ::: Sample Collection ::: Deer Mouse ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: There is limited information available in the literature regarding hematology parameters in the deer mouse.
body_text.section: Blood ::: Sample Collection ::: Deer Mouse ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: Reference values for erythrocytes in the deer mouse are provided in Table 3.9.
body_text.section: Erythrocytes ::: Peripheral Blood Cells ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Deer Mouse ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: The reference range for red blood cell count in the deer mouse is 10–12×106 cells per µl (Table 3.9).
body_text.section: Red Blood Cell Count ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Deer Mouse ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: The reference range for hematocrit in the deer mouse is 38–52% (Table 3.9).
body_text.section: Hematocrit (Hct) or Packed Cell Volume (PCV) ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Deer Mouse ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: Deer mice infected with Cuterebra sp. were found to have lower packed cell volumes than uninfected deer mice (Sealander, 1961). By contrast, deer mice infected with Capillaria hepatica had elevated hematocrits compared with uninfected controls (Meagher, 1998).
body_text.section: Hematocrit (Hct) or Packed Cell Volume (PCV) ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Deer Mouse ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: The reference range for hemoglobin concentration in the deer mouse is 12–16 g/dl (Table 3.9).
body_text.section: Hemoglobin (Hgb) ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Deer Mouse ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: Deer mice infected with Cuterebra sp. were found to have a lower hemoglobin concentration than uninfected deer mice trapped during the same period (Sealander, 1961).
body_text.section: Hemoglobin (Hgb) ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Deer Mouse ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: The reference range for MCV in the deer mouse is 36–46 µ3 (Table 3.9).
body_text.section: Mean Cell Volume (MCV) ::: Erythrocyte Size and Staining ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Deer Mouse ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: The reference range for MCH in the deer mouse is 11–15 pg per cell (Table 3.9).
body_text.section: Mean Cell Hemoglobin (MCH) ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Deer Mouse ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: The reference range for MCHC in the deer mouse is 30–35 g/dl (Table 3.9).
body_text.section: Mean Cell Hemoglobin Concentration (MCHC) ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Deer Mouse ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: The reference range for total leukocyte number in the deer mouse is 1–4×103 cells per µl (Table 3.10).
body_text.section: Total White Blood Cell (WBC) Count ::: Leukocytes ::: Deer Mouse ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: There is no information available in the literature regarding hematology values in the dormouse.
body_text.section: Dormouse ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: A discussion of blood sample methods and collection sites in the kangaroo rat is presented above in the Clinical Biochemistry section of this chapter.
body_text.section: Blood ::: Sample Collection ::: Kangaroo Rat ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: Reference values for erythrocyte characteristics in the kangaroo rat are provided in Table 3.9.
body_text.section: Erythrocytes ::: Peripheral Blood Cells ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Kangaroo Rat ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: The reference range for red blood cell count in the kangaroo rat is 7–9×106 per µl (Table 3.9). Values are lowest in the winter and highest in the summer (Intress and Best, 1990).
body_text.section: Red Blood Cell Count ::: Peripheral Blood Cells ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Kangaroo Rat ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: The reference range for hematocrit in the kangaroo rat is 47–53% (Table 3.9). Values are lowest in the summer and highest in the winter (Scelza and Knoll, 1982).
body_text.section: Hematocrit (Hct) or Packed Cell Volume (PCV) ::: Peripheral Blood Cells ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Kangaroo Rat ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: The reference range for hemoglobin concentration in the kangaroo rat is 15–17 g/dl (Table 3.9). Values are fairly consistent throughout the year (Scelza and Knoll, 1982).
body_text.section: Hemoglobin (Hgb) ::: Peripheral Blood Cells ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Kangaroo Rat ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: The reference range for MCV in the kangaroo rat is 57.3–663 (Table 3.9).
body_text.section: Mean Cell Volume (MCV) ::: Erythrocyte Size and Staining ::: Peripheral Blood Cells ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Kangaroo Rat ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: The reference range for MCH in the kangaroo rat is 18.6–25 pg per cell (Table 3.9). Values are lowest in the summer and variably higher during the other seasons (Intress and Best, 1990).
body_text.section: Mean Cell Hemoglobin (MCH) ::: Peripheral Blood Cells ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Kangaroo Rat ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: The reference range for MCHC in the kangaroo rat is 30–35 g/dl (Table 3.9). Values are fairly consistent throughout the year (Scelza and Knoll, 1982).
body_text.section: Mean Cell Hemoglobin Concentration (MCHC) ::: Peripheral Blood Cells ::: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Kangaroo Rat ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: The reference range for total leukocyte number in the kangaroo rat is 3–9×103 per µl (Table 3.10). Values are highest in the spring and variable during the other seasons (Intress and Best, 1990, Scelza and Knoll, 1982).
body_text.section: Total White Blood Cell (WBC) Count ::: Leukocytes ::: Kangaroo Rat ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: Blood collection in the cotton rat is described in the Clinical Biochemistry section of this chapter.
body_text.section: Blood ::: Sample Collection ::: Cotton Rat ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: Reference values for erythrocyte characteristics in the cotton rat are provided in Table 3.9.
body_text.section: Erythrocytes ::: Peripheral Blood Cells ::: Reference Values and Unique Characterstics ::: Cotton Rat ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: Cotton rats exposed to 1000 ppm lead in drinking water showed decreased erythrocyte indices in a dose-dependent manner (McMurry et al., 1995).
body_text.section: Erythrocytes ::: Peripheral Blood Cells ::: Reference Values and Unique Characterstics ::: Cotton Rat ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: The reference range for hemoglobin concentration in the cotton rat is 13–14 g/dl (Table 3.9).
body_text.section: Hemoglobin (Hgb) ::: Peripheral Blood Cells ::: Reference Values and Unique Characterstics ::: Cotton Rat ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: The reference range for total leukocyte number in the cotton rat is 11–13×103 cells per µl (Table 3.10).
body_text.section: Total White Blood Cell (WBC) Count ::: Leukocytes ::: Cotton Rat ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: Several studies have examined the effect of diet and environmental conditions on hematology and immune function of the cotton rat.
body_text.section: Total White Blood Cell (WBC) Count ::: Leukocytes ::: Cotton Rat ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: Immunocompetence has been suggested as an important influence on survival in herbivore populations (Robel et al., 1996). Supplementation of food quantity and quality (enhanced methionine) did not have a consistent effect on hematology or immune function in adult male cotton rats, although total leukocyte number was increased (Webb et al., 2003).
body_text.section: Total White Blood Cell (WBC) Count ::: Leukocytes ::: Cotton Rat ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: Cotton rats exposed to 1000 ppm lead in drinking water showed decreased total leukocytes in a dose-dependent manner (McMurry et al., 1995).
body_text.section: Total White Blood Cell (WBC) Count ::: Leukocytes ::: Cotton Rat ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: The reference range for lymphocyte number in the cotton rat is 50–54% (Table 3.10).
body_text.section: Lymphocytes ::: Leukocytes ::: Cotton Rat ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: The reference range for neutrophil number in the cotton rat is 36–40% (Table 3.10).
body_text.section: Neutrophils (Heterophils) ::: Leukocytes ::: Cotton Rat ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: The reference range for eosinophil number in the cotton rat is 5–6% (Table 3.10).
body_text.section: Eosinophils ::: Leukocytes ::: Cotton Rat ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: The reference range for basophil number in the cotton rat is 0–0.2% (Table 3.10).
body_text.section: Basophils ::: Leukocytes ::: Cotton Rat ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: The reference range for monocyte number in the cotton rat is 4–5% (Table 3.10).
body_text.section: Monocytes ::: Leukocytes ::: Cotton Rat ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: Supplementation of food quantity and quality (enhanced methionine) increased platelet number in the cotton rat (Webb et al., 2003).
body_text.section: Platelets (Thrombocytes) ::: Cotton Rat ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: There is very little information available on hematology parameters in the sand rat.
body_text.section: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Blood ::: Sample Collection ::: Sand Rat ::: Other Rodents

body_text.text: A study in sand rats found that glucose concentration within red blood cells is higher than in plasma of this species, as it is in other mammals. This phenomenon was explained by loose binding of glucose to macromolecules within the erythrocyte (Halperin and Adler, 1985).
body_text.section: Reference Values and Unique Characteristics ::: Blood ::: Sample Collection ::: Sand Rat ::: Other Rodents
